Award.AbstractNarration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award will support the progress of science and advance the national prosperity and welfare by transforming how urban systems researchers use data analytics in their studies. Scientific progress in many operational problems in urban mobility, energy and water usage, public safety, and healthcare is limited by lack of access to real-world data. Currently, new models and algorithms developed by the operations research community are often tested on simulated datasets that may not reflect real operating conditions. Research supported by this project will enable the creation of a novel Computational Operations Research Exchange (CORE) platform that aims to overcome these limitations. CORE platform will allow researchers from different disciplines to leverage actual operational data and compare their methods and results on realistic scenarios. The exchange platform will also provide a mechanism to encourage cross-disciplinary collaborations, which are important to innovative solutions to complex societal problems.

The project will use a Systems-of-Systems approach to build a re-usable cyber-infrastructure for operations research models. With today's availability of open access public datasets, the platform will provide a plug-and-play paradigm which can share data, models and algorithms in a seamless manner, allowing researchers to effectively compare algorithms on real datasets. The project will begin with three use-cases drawn from applications in energy, transportation, and urban analytics. The PIs will design protocols so that these applications will be instantiated using data available across many different regions in the country, thus allowing models of similar scope to be tested using regional datasets. The platform will provide generic model interfaces, where alternative model types will be allowed to work on common datasets for comparison purposes. The PIs are committed to working closely with women and
minorities and will involve two women Ph.D students in this project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to create a cyberinfrastructure which will facilitate computational Operations Research (OR) exchange.  OR models arise in many engineering domains, such as design, manufacturing, and services (e.g., banking/finance, health systems), as well as specific infrastructure-centric applications such as health care delivery, logistics, power system operations, supply chains, telecommunications, traffic/transportation, and many more.  In addition, modern OR tools have also been adopted in many foundational disciplines, such as artificial intelligence, computer science, control systems, statistics, and others. 

Given the broad footprint of OR, the development of a robust cyberinfrastructure has the potential to not only promote i) greater exchange of data, models, software, and experiments but also ii) enhance reproducibility and re-usability, both within OR, and across multiple disciplines mentioned above.  cORe has the potential to drastically reduce the computational burden on research communities which study resource allocation and analytics. A final goal of the project is iii) to enhance pedagogy through a common repository of open source analytics projects so that students and others new to the field are able to learn about the broad class of mathematical models used in modern enterprises.

Given the goals outlined above, we seeded the cORe platform with about 25 use-cases, some of which are classified as pedagogical, others are somewhat advanced, and still others are challenge-level instances.  The pedagogical ones are less demanding, and they are intended to help users become familiar with basic structure associated with many computationally oriented projects involving the trio of models, data and algorithms.  Moreover, all our use-cases have a focus on decisions, although we do include certain aspects of data science which provide predictions, that are to be ultimately used for making decisions.

  1. Decision Intelligence for Allocating Ventilators during  COVID-19 using Predictions from infectious disease models, together with decisions resulting from Rolling-Horizon Procedures (also known as Model Predictive Control in Chemical Engineering) using a sequence of  large scale Stochastic Linear Programming models (SLP), solved using Stochastic Decomposition (SD) which has been a workhorse of large scale SLP.  The experiments reported here show how combining predictive and prescriptive analytics can help save lives by reducing ventillator shortages during peak demand periods.
  2. Stochastic Facility Location (very large scale Stochastic Mixed-Integer Programming) for locating warehouses in a megalopolis of the size of LA, with cost-structures that vary day-upon-day because of operational variability is cities of the size of LA.  Such models lead to highly non-convex stochastic optimization models.   And yet, we can report decisions with fairly close bounds on optimality, implying reasonably reliable decisions.
  3. Is Renewable Integration a Feasible Goal?   We study Renewable Integration in a Power Grid by transforming a stack of deterministic hierarchical planning with a stack of stochastic planning models.  This was tested using a new renewable energy test-bed known as NREL-118 (a dataset developed by NREL - National Renewable Energy Labs).  Our study produces results which demonstrate that it may be possible to transition to high renewable energy penetration by replacing current methods of Deterministic Optimization by new tools from Stochastic Optimization.  Because of cORe, it is possible to other researchers to reproduce our results on one of the most important questions of our time: Is High Renewable Penetration even feasible?  Our study suggests that the answer is "Yes", and users of the cORe system are invited to reproduce our study to convince themselves of the results we have produced.
  4. Several Pedagogical Use-cases have be developed for class projects in graduate courses for Analytics.  These projects include new models which emphasize the integration of data and decision sciences, also known as the integration of predictive and presciptive analytics.  These projects are now used in a graduate course within M.S. in Analytics at USC.  Finally, we have also obtained sponsorship from Amazon Web Services (AWS) to run contests in which students are invited to solve real-scale models, and the winners are those whose approaches are judged most realistic by a panel of judges from Amazon and academe.
